Mark Farrell

More Self-Dual Coherent Algebras

Feb 16, 2018

I would like to establish some more examples of families of self-dual coherent algebras, in addition to the prototypical example of a family of self-dual coherent algebras arising from finite abelian groups that I established in my last post.

Suppose that and are commutative coherent algebras of order .

A duality mapping from to is a linear isomorphism such that:

  1. for all .

  2. for all .

I would like to assume the fact that the tensor product of two commutative coherent algebras is self-dual if there is a duality mapping between them.

Then as a first additional example of a family of self-dual coherent algebras:

  • Suppose that is a self-complementary strongly-regular graph of order .

    Assume that is connected and -regular.

    Then has three distinct eigenvalues for some , since it is strongly-regular and self-complementary.

    Moreover:

    for some permutation matrix and orthogonal projection such that , letting denote the adjacency matrix of and denote the all-ones matrix in .

    Now, let denote the linear automorphism on such that , , and .

    [ again, since is self-complementary ]

    Observe now that is a commutative coherent algebra and that for all .

    It can then be concluded that is a self-dual coherent algebra, since for all by construction as well.

So, self-dual coherent algebras can be constructed from e.g. self-complementary arc-transitive graphs in this way, for instance.

Now, a complex square matrix (of order ) is said to be Schur-invertible with Schur-inverse if for some (unique) matrix and all-ones matrix .

The Nomura algebra (of order ) of a Schur-invertible matrix is defined as ; the Nomura algebra of Schur-invertible matrix is a subspace of complex square matrices that is closed under ordinary matrix multiplication with identity.

A Schur-invertible matrix of order is said to be Type-II if .

I would like to construct a second example of a family of self-dual coherent algebras from Nomura algebras of Type-II matrices:

  1. Let denote the linear mapping such that for all and , for any Schur-invertible matrix (of order ).

  2. Suppose that is a Type-II matrix of order .

    Select any .

    Then for all :

    [ since is Type-II ]

    .

    [ noting that is also Type-II ].

    By similar reasoning, it follows that .

    It is then ultimately apparent that is closed under transposition in general.

    Observe moreover that is in fact a linear isomorphism (with inverse ): hence it is ultimately apparent too that is closed under Schur-product (since is closed under ordinary matrix multiplication).

    Since is Type-II, it immediately follows that the all-ones matrix is in as well.

    Hence it can be established here that is a coherent algebra; indeed, is a commutative coherent algebra since for all .

    It can then be similarly seen that is a commutative coherent algebra as well.

    It is then apparent that is a duality mapping between commutative coherent algebras and : since maps Schur-primitive matrices in to their Schur-primitive transpose in , it is necessary that maps Schur-primitive matrices in to primitive matrices in and moreover that for all .

    Finally, it can then be concluded here that the tensor product of Nomura algebras and for the Type-II matrix is a self-dual coherent algebra.

So, self-dual coherent algebras can indeed be constructed from Type-II matrices; complex Hadamard matrices are a first example of a family of Type-II matrices that comes to mind, which moreover can e.g. be constructed from character tables of finite abelian groups and graphs that admit uniform mixing (with respect to their continuous-time quantum walks relative to their adjacency matrices).

I would now lastly like to establish that the adjacency algebras of Hamming graphs are self-dual coherent algebras:

  • Suppose that is the -th direct power of some finite cyclic group and .

    Let denote the coherent algebra arising from as in my previous posts: i.e. where is a -matrix relating pairs of elements of whose difference is (and hence also a permutation matrix representation the left-translation of the elements of by ) for all .

    Additionally, let denote a Hamming weight function on : i.e. a function mapping elements of to their number of non-zero coordinates.

    Partition the elements of according to their Hamming weight: define for all .

    For all , let denote the -matrix in relating pairs of elements of whose difference has Hamming weight :

    i.e. for all .

    Define .

    Note that , since is abelian and hence for all since is abelian.

    It is then apparent that is a commutative coherent subalgebra of , observing that can be identified with the adjacency algebra of a Hamming graph (which is a commutative coherent algebra, assuming the fact that Hamming graphs are distance-regular).

    Now, recall too from a previous post that the set of irreducible characters of can be indexed in such a way that for all (and that is self-dual under the character table of relative to this way of indexing the irreducible characters of ).

    Observe too then that depends only on the Hamming weight of for all and all , which essentially follows from the the fact that is a direct power of a finite cyclic group.

    Define the matrix as for all .

    From previous posts, it then follows is character table for .

    Note too that , since is the adjacency algebra of distance-regular graph and hence every Schur-primitive matrix in is a Hermitian matrix (whose distinct eigenvalues are all real).

    Lastly, for all , define as where is defined as for all and .

    It then be observed that and that for all .

    Moreover, it follows from the fact the irreducible characters of form an orthonormal basis for the vector space of complex-valued functions on that each is idempotent for all .

    Hence it can be concluded that is the set of primitive matrices in and that is a self-dual coherent algebra.

It turns out that, conversely, the adjacency algebra of every Hamming graph can be identified with an instance of this kind of coherent algebra arising from a finite cyclic group as well; hence the adjacency algebras of Hamming graphs are indeed self-dual.

So, indeed there are some arguably interesting families of self-dual coherent algebras that can be constructed aside from the prototypical example of a family of self-dual coherent algebras arising from finite abelian groups that I established in my previous post. I hope to continue to e.g. construct even more examples of self-dual coherent algebras in future posts towards e.g. completely classifying certain families of self-dual coherent algebras, such as certain families of distance-regular graphs whose adjacency algebras are self-dual.
